replies.text: No state or local taxes is one of the benefits of buying United States Treasurys basically the debt of the United States. And that 4.55 yield is about what youd get from Tbills. So Id guess its some sort of US Treasury fund, where Nerd Wallet takes a little cut of the yield in exchange for giving you some liquidity. But atomic idk what thats about.

It seems ok, securities are SIPC insured like at brokerages, savings are FDIC insured so it should be a bank like any other. But for me I already have a brokerage account where I can buy treasuries on the secondary market, and I already have a bank with HYSA, and I have a treasurydirect account for Ibonds where I can buy treasury ladders if I want. I dont see the need to complicate it further just because they have a better website and app than treasurydirect.
Dont you have to pay annually for the nerd wallet subscription thing? No thanks.

The Atomic Treasury Account gives you around 4.55 APY, which is better than what youd get from most savings accounts, and you can access your money anytime. Its based on U.S. Treasury bills, so your interest is exempt from state and local taxes, which can help if you live in a hightax area. Theres no minimum balance, but since Tbills are bought in 100 increments, its good to keep at least that much in your account. Just be aware that there may be some management fees that could eat into your returns a bit. NerdWallet, Banktruth and Bankrate are all reliable sources. Theyre essentially aggregators of rates for HYSA, CDs, etc.
probably means theyre slicing up the bonds into tiny parts to sell to people ... ie those that cant buy 1000 worth at a time.
Name of the company
Join NerdWallet Become a member for 49year to get exclusive access to the Atomic Treasury account
Good question, I have no idea!
Thank you! Are there any other risks with this type of account or just possible fees? Does it work just as a savings account or more like an investment?
SGOV trades at about 100share.

Its more like an investment account, but what is being invested is very safe because its directly backed by the US government treasuries, probably safer than a savings account tbh with all the banking regulatory issues going around. As VenJules mentioned the other added benefit is exemption from statelocal taxes, which depending on your tax rate etc could add a pretty hefty chunk of net of tax yield compared to a standard savings account
SGOV does not return 4.55 a month. US treasuries do. at least currently. SGOV always falls short of the actual treasuries by a few basis points.
Good to know.....best for long or short term? Does it lock you in, in any way?

Reading their offering it looks more short term 4 week treasury bills but you can withdraw at any time and they will sell your shares on the secondary market in that case. If you dont withdraw anything the Treasury investments continue getting automatically rolled over into new 4 week investments upon maturity

Yes, as a loss it would reduce your taxable income. Its usually used when people are selling stocks that did make them a profit.
If you have a stock that you sell at a profit. Pick the stock with equivalent loss and sell at the same time. Gains and losses then offset.

And this loss is actually not too bad. You will see that once you are filing tax return next year. Note that do not rebuy this stock within 30 days after selling. I would just move on and dont even care that they exist or they up big as soon as you sell.
You can offset capital gains with losses. You would need to sell the stocks to realize the loss before you can write anything off

Most large important companies will not lose 90 of its value that means theyre sliding into obscurity like Kodak. From a mathematical pov Suppose the original value of the shares is 100. After losing 90, the value drops to 10. To get back to 100 from 10, the shares need to increase by 90. In percentage terms, this is calculated as frac9010 times 100 900. Its not going up 900...

My financial advisor told me the same information that you can write off up to 3,000 of regular income from Capital losses and then any other Capital losses can only be applied to capital gains, but you can keep track and carry over more Capital losses to write off up to 3000 from your regular income the next year as well
Damn, sorry. Did I miss who asked you?
Not you bro. Step off your wrong high horse.
this was my understandinginstruction also.
deleted

Of course its true. This is a basic tenet of tax loss harvesting. After offsetting capital gains, remaining loss can offset ordinary income up to 3000 per year, and any further remaining amounts being able to be carried forward to future tax years.
I think this depends on the tax rules of a country. I know for sure in Canada capital losses cant offset normal income except year of death. The 3k rule someone mentioned applies in US.
Its absolutely true.
Yes sorry, I forget that everyone here is not from the same place. My comments were applicable for Australia.

5g from space works by using very large phased arrays that use beam forming to pick up signal from cellphones and low power devices. For the frequencies AST partners up with MNO around the world to use their spectrum. The FCC is actually finalizing the framework for spectrum reuse from space in the US, called SCS supplemental coverage from space. So AST does not have to acquire spectrum or spectrum rights. AST is partnered up with ATT and Verizon in the US for spectrum reuse. They have memorandum of understanding with over 40 other mobile network operators worldwide

America has basically unlimited natural gas, and better gas distribution infrastructure than power distribution infrastructure in most instances. How is Elon powering his 5bn cluster in Texas? With natural gas... Using standalone emergency generators, which are topped up by grid power from the natural gas plant down the road. Which method of electrical power generation is the cheapest, the quickest to come online, and works 24 hours a day without batteries? Natural gas How are Amazon and Intel data centres powered? With clean fuel cell technology... Yep, powered by natural gas The AI race is a race... Noone is gonna wait around for SMR technology to be developed and go through ten years of regulatory hurdles and then scale up and go through another ten years of regulatory hurdles for implementation. They want power yesterday. Theyre sprinting for AGI by 2030. Microsoft and OpenAI and the rest will be forced to use natural gas just to keep up pace with their competition in the US who burn natural gas and their competition in China who burn coal. Nuclear is a meme which big tech ESG teams are distracting you with to green wash their plans to build their gas powered superclusters. Downvote below.

Just to add some fun facts for everyone. There are currently two active cesium mines in the world, one in Africa and one in Manitoba, Canada. Both are operated by Sinomine Chinese owned. The mine in Manitoba has a short mine life ahead of it. To lengthen the mine life of the Tanco mine, Sinomine is currently asking to drain the lake above it so they can chase the ore closer to the surface. I could very well see this new project being pushed forward as an act of globalnational security. Mining is a very slow and expensive process though, so its always a risky play. Always a chance this producer gets close to money, then bankrupts itself and goes into production under a different name.
